text:
YVONNE NG: Thank you,
everyone for joining us today. It is so special to be able to
have this discussion with you

because we love
our OCW learners. You're all so curious
and so full of ideas.

Any time we get to hear directly
from you is inspiring to us. What we hope you take away
today are some of the ways

that OCW broadens our outreach. And we also want to hear
from you, especially

on what's resonating with
you about what we're doing and how you would love
to connect with OCW.

I'm Yvonne Ng. I help run the annual
giving and donor relations for MIT Open Learning.

We're still celebrating 20
years of OpenCourseWare, reaching more than 200 million
people around the world.

And we know that that
growth of the site is due to you sharing OCW
with your friends, families,

and colleagues. Everyone who has used
or supported the site has become part of the
OCW family in a sense.

And that family is a wonderful
community eager to learn, share what you've learned
to uplift yourself

or your own communities. So just a couple of
housekeeping notes. Today's discussion will
be recorded and shared

with our community. Your participation today
indicates your willingness to share your likeness
and any comments

you make in this recording. If you're tuning in on the Zoom
link and would like captions,

please click on the CC button
at the bottom of your screen. To ask a question,
type it in the Q&A box.

Today, I'm happy to have three
amazing OCW team members who have been key in
raising awareness of OCW

and supporting folks
in a special way. And with that, I'll ask
our wonderful speakers
to briefly introduce themselves. SARAH HANSEN: Thanks, Yvonne.

My name is Sarah Hansen. And I lead the educator
initiative at OpenCourseWare. And that means my job is to make
the content that OCW produces

more valuable to educators
on a global scale. I think I have one of
the best jobs at MIT

because I get to support
educators like many of you out there. I'll turn it over to one
of my colleagues next.
CHERYL SIEGEL: Hi. I'm Cheryl Siegel.

I wear two hats here at OCW. Most of my time is spent
creating course content

for all of you and
working with the faculty.

But on my other hat is that
I get to manage social media. And this is the most fun job.

No offense, Sarah. I think my job
might be more fun. But I can play on social
media in the name of research.

And it's a great
way to be creative. And best of all, I get
to connect with you. And I just wanted
to share that when

I came for my original
interview at OWC I was sitting in the room
waiting for my interviewers

to come in. And I just had this feeling
that this is my job.

This is where I'm meant to be. And so that was 13 years ago. And I'm really excited to
come to work every day.

So thank you. And I'm going to turn
it over to Sharon.

SHARON LIN: Hi, everyone. My name is Sharon Lin. I am a digital publication
specialist at OCW.

I went to graduate
school at MIT and I have been working at OCW since 2012.

One of my major
responsibilities is to coordinate the OCW
Mirror Site program, which

is about serving global
learning communities with limited internet access.

YVONNE NG: Thank you, guys. That's awesome. So before we dive
in, we will start off

with one of our
burning questions to this wonderful
audience of OCW learners.

We want to know how do you
love to connect with OCW? And so we're going
to launch a poll.

And we hope that you'll
choose one of these options, whether it's the website, social
media, Chalk Radio Podcast,

newsletter, and others. So if you can, take a
moment and cast your vote.

And then we'll just give it
another couple of seconds before we close the poll. But I kind of feel like I know.

I kind of feel like I know. But I won't know until
you guys tell us.
Haha! The website. It's true. But you know what's really cool?

I love that you guys
hear through us-- you get to us
through social media. But Chalk Radio Podcast is
one of our newest ventures.

And it's awesome that
you guys know about it.

So the first question I'm going
to pose to my colleagues here is can you talk about
some of the work

you do to build communities
of learners and educators? And perhaps some of the things
that have surprised you?

And we'll start off with
our good friend Sarah. SARAH HANSEN: Hi.

So I try to build community
with our OCW followers

mainly by telling the human
story of open education. And I do that by
interviewing MIT faculty

about how they teach and sharing
that in lots of different ways. But the latest way is through
the Chalk Radio Podcast, which

I have the honor of hosting. It's so fun. And we really created the
podcast for you out there.

We wanted to create a
sense of community for you. We bring you into
conversation with some of the most interesting
faculty on campus

who are doing really interesting
courses and research. And we want you to feel like
you're under the dome with us

and that you're walking
down the Infinite Corridor with those faculty members. And we want you to
be inspired to learn

just like we are every day. So that's my main effort these
days in creating community.

It's been really an
exciting journey. We have listeners from
all six continents so far.

We don't have the penguins
in Antarctica yet, but I'm working on that. We have over 300,000 listens
across different platforms

and venues. So it's just been great. And I guess the thing
that surprised me

the most is how many
people reach out to us who also want to share the
human story of open education.

At conferences we have
a lot of people asking how they can do similar work.

And so that's been
a wonderful surprise to go from a novice
in this area--

I didn't know how to
produce podcasts-- to having something to share
and to help other people do the same thing.

So I'll end there
so we can hear more. YVONNE NG: That's
so awesome Sarah. I love your podcast.

It's just it really-- you guys have been able
to really cultivate a special relationship
with each of the people
that you interview. So thank you for that. Sharon? Over to you.

SHARON LIN: So the
Mirror Site program is serving the communities
with unmet educational needs.

Every time when I prepare a
portable hard drive, which contains a copy of the
content on our life site,

and when I put that little
hard drive into a shipping box, the box can look
pretty ordinary just

like any of the Amazon packages. But I imagine that from
the recipient's end

the hard drive can bring hope,
inspiration, life changing knowledge that
will benefit people

who may not be able to
be on the MIT campus but equally so desire to learn.

And one of the most
surprising moments is that I have shipped
these hard drives to places

around the world
both domestically and internationally, including
Haiti, Myanmar, Somalia,

and one time a US Navy submarine
with an undisclosed location.
That was pretty cool. YVONNE NG: Oh my gosh. I love that you do that.

I remember I actually used
to ship out those drives way, way long back in the day.

And those drives used to be at
least like a good five pounds. It's amazing that the drives
are as big as your hand.

So kudos to technology. Cheryl, do you want to tell
us a little bit about some

of the work you do
to build community and perhaps something
that surprised you? CHERYL SIEGEL: Absolutely.

So I've been working our
social media channels now for a couple of years. And I'm really honored
to have inherited

some well established accounts
with half a million people

on Facebook. And so we have
Facebook, Twitter. I also just started
an Instagram account.

And I'm on a march
to 10,000 followers. We plan to get there
by the end of the year. And we also have LinkedIn
for professionals.

And the hardest part is how
do I get you guys to notice us

in this infinite scroll? I think about that as I do
my own surfing on the web,
on Facebook, or whatever. What gets me to stop? What is interesting?

And what blends into the fray? And OCW doesn't have
a built in community

of learners like in the
way that a MOOC might where you have a group of people
taking a course all together.

And we've tried many
experiments over the years. And they haven't worked
for a variety of reasons.

So I think social media is
de facto become that place.

And so thinking of
it as I'm curating a community of learners, that's
a guiding principle for me.

So not only do I want to hear
from you and to share with you, but I want all of you to
talk to each other as well.

So I really strive
to be interactive. There is a lot of just, hey,
we have this great new course

on nuclear engineering. But it's also I want back
and forth conversations.

I've been chatting with someone
on Instagram messenger trying to help him figure out the
best course and how it works.

So don't be shy. Feel free to reach out. And I love hearing about your
ideas and what makes you angry

or what doesn't
make sense to you. I find people aren't too
shy about these things.

And I think the
greatest skill or gift that I've honed
through these years is to really get a better
understanding of who

our audience is, who you are. So I don't just post OCW
related things, although I do.

But I also want to
repost and share articles about
science and technology and pop culture that might
be of interest to you.

Or maybe some obscure
Star Wars reference that only you guys might get.

But the thing that surprises
me most is that you cannot get enough nerd humor
in all its forms.

I try really hard for
holiday themed ones. The Thanksgiving ones
are particularly good.

Go back and look. But I do have a
confession-- that I don't have a STEM background.

And I continue to be surprised
by the massive amount of interest in things
I do not understand.

So for instance, linear algebra. Professor Gil Strang is
an aging mathematician

teaching linear algebra. But he is like a rock star here. Whenever I post
anything about Gil,

we get hundreds of
responses about how he's changed people's lives.

And so at the end
of the day, that's what really keeps me going. So again, don't be shy.

Reach out. I'd love to hear from you.  YVONNE NG: Thanks
so much, Cheryl.

I absolutely adore
all the work that you put in to all of our
social media sites. You have been really able to
cultivate a beautiful community

that's supportive of each other
and have very strong opinions. And, I think, that's
what we love to hear.

But we also love to hear
from our learning community just about their experience.

And I've been so lucky
to have read so many OCW stories from folks who just
describe how OCW has helped

them fill their educational gaps
or skill up for their careers.

Would y'all take a moment and
share with us a story from the community, perhaps how
somebody used OCW that inspired

you to keep sharing
OCW with the world? And we'll start off with Sharon.

SHARON LIN: Yes. So our goal is try to reach
out to a diverse group

of underprivileged
learners in the world. For example, recently I have
spent mirror drives to prison

in order to serve the
incarcerated students. Keep in mind that these
students do not have any freedom

to access the internet yet still
have the opportunity to learn. And we definitely receive
letters all the time

from these students
about how much they appreciate this very
special learning opportunity.
YVONNE NG: That's amazing. I'm in the office.

And just today, I just picked
up three different letters from inmates who just--

they have this huge desire
to improve themselves and they're learning even though
they're still incarcerated.

So it's wonderful that
you're able to share that. Sarah, did you want
to share a story?

SARAH HANSEN: Sure. Well, I'm all about educators. And if there are
any of you out there

who are teachers or
instructors or TAs just let me know in the chat. I'd just love to hear that.

So my favorite story
is about a professor that I met at Worcester
State University.

Her name is Elizabeth Seiler. Check her out. She's great. She reused and remixed materials
from one of the earliest

courses that we published on
OCW way back in the early 2000s.

And she made them relevant
and important for her business students today. And she even remixed
the level of-- she

took a graduate level
course and made it appropriate for undergraduates. I was really moved
by this story.

And so I had her on the podcast. And we brought her and
the original professor onto the podcast to talk to each
other about the power of Open

and what it does for learning. And it was just such
a privilege to be part of that conversation.

And it inspires me to keep doing
this work and to keep sharing. And in a second I'll drop
that episode in the chat
if anyone wants to check it out. YVONNE NG: My gosh. I love that.

I mean, that's exactly
what we want people to do. We want people to use,
remix, distribute, share

our resources. And if people are doing
that, then we're winning. This is awesome.

Cheryl, did you want
to share your story?  CHERYL SIEGEL: You know
you work in a good place

when it's hard to find one
answer to this question.

We get daily stories. And so we're so lucky. But the one that
has stayed with me

is from a man who was in
Afghanistan in the military and was hit by a roadside
bomb and had traumatic brain

disorder. And his whole life
was disrupted. And no longer could
he sit in a classroom

and learn in the same way
for a variety of reasons. It was just too hard
for him medically.

And so he talked
about how OCW was really instrumental in
helping him find his way back

because he could learn at his
own pace, at his own time. And this was before
MOOCs were a thing.

So it was one of the
fewer options out there. And so being able to
access the knowledge

was able to help him
get to the next steps. So I don't think I'll
ever forget that one.

It stayed with me. YVONNE NG: That's
such an amazing story. Thank you so much
for sharing that.

We're going to just
slightly switch gears here

because in putting
on this discussion, we invited you all to
send in your feedback,

send in your suggestions on
how we can do our work better

in terms of raising awareness. And more than 400
people signed up.

And we actually had more than
250 suggestions that we're kind of working through.

And we're so appreciative. And so we've actually
received lots of ideas about how OCW can
improve our awareness building

and outreach efforts. For you panelists, what kind
of community feedback or input

is or would be helpful to
you and your outreach work? Cheryl, we'll start with you.

CHERYL SIEGEL: I
would actually like to answer a question
from YouTube from Braden

about how we got our social
media accounts to the levels that we did.

And as I mentioned, I
inherited many of these. So I wasn't present
at the beginning.

But my understanding
is that we did end up having to run paid ads that--

we don't have a huge budget. We're not like
Toyota or something. But we did do
campaigns and boosting.

And that was eventually
what got it there. But you also have
to remember there

was a lot less
competition for your eyes out there at the time.

Five, 10 years ago. Whenever this was. And so it wasn't as
competitive as it is now.

Or crowded, I
guess, is the word. But, I guess, I'm really
interested to know
what makes you stop and read?

People seem to
really love video. Do you want more video in
our social media accounts?

Do you want me to include
links to problem sets.

I would just love more
guidance about what it is you need from us.

I mean, is it enough to just
put in a link to a course that we've just published
and say, off you go.

So any kind of feedback
people have about that would be super helpful to me.

YVONNE NG: And then
Sharon, did you want to go?

SHARON LIN: Sure. So for the Mirror Site
program, currently, we have 437 affiliates globally.

We want the Mirror Site to
continue to grow and provide equitable access to education
for learners around the world.

On the recipients
end, I think, we are always curious
about questions such as how effective are those
hard drives we have provided.

Do they work? Any technical glitches? How are they set up to
encourage new learners?

On the other hand,
we will always appreciate if people can support
us to continue this program

or help us figure out a
technology invention to further grow the program. So let's just keep
the ball rolling.
YVONNE NG: That's great. Thanks so much for that.

Sarah, did you want to
tell us a little bit more about what kind of
feedback is going to be helpful to you and your team?

SARAH HANSEN: Yeah. There's really two parts. One, we love to bring your
voices into the podcast.

We have a telephone
number that you can call to tell
us who you'd like to see as guests on the
show or what questions

you have for them. But I would love to
know from you, how can I invite you to do that?

How can we communicate
about that? Do you like social media for
invitations to submit ideas?

What works best for you? The second piece is
that we love to talk

about what OCW does for
educators and can do for them. We love to present
at conferences.

So my ask is if you have
local conferences where you are, please let us know
if you'd like us to come share

the resources that we have. Now with Zoom, we can
appear almost anywhere.

And we'd love to come to you. So please reach out
and let us know.

YVONNE NG: That's just great. That's just great. As I mentioned
before, we actually had so many people writing
in and just offering

these great suggestions. So our panelists are going
to choose a suggestion that
was offered and expand upon it. And so we'll start with Sarah.

SARAH HANSEN: Well, I
actually just did that. I took that suggestion for
conferences, which I thought was just great.

And it's something we
already love to do. So just another plug
to please reach out and let us know about
any local conferences.
I would love to come. YVONNE NG: And for Sharon?

SHARON LIN: Yes. So I looked at all
of the questions our participants had raised.

And I think several
people mentioned about seeking collaboration
with other institutes

or other websites. And I think for the Mirror
Site program particularly, partners played an
instrumental role

in extending our
outreach to more hard to reach learners' communities. For example, we have worked
with our affiliate in Myanmar

and successfully brought
MIT course materials to 23 universities and six
community libraries in Myanmar.

The door for collaboration
is always open. And we will continue to
look for a new partnership.
YVONNE NG: That's wonderful. That's so great.

Cheryl, did you want
to take a suggestion and perhaps expand upon it?

CHERYL SIEGEL: Well, there
were some suggestions that said be on social media more.

And so I wasn't quite sure
if that meant post more or be on different platforms.

And we do have a poll
question coming up about that. But yeah, so I think my
goal is to post often--

every day or nearly every
day to get you guys-- to keep you engaged.

So yeah, I think knowing which
platforms are the right ones
is one of my challenges. It's like, do we go to TikTok?

Should we check out Clubhouse? And then I'm sure there are many
that I've never heard of yet

because I'm too old. But I think that's one of the
bigger challenges I have is

I know that many of our users
are on TikTok and WhatsApp.

And it doesn't make
sense for us to go there. I don't know. But we just did Instagram. And that's going pretty well.

But there had been resistance
about it previously. So here's your poll about
if you could only spend time

on one social media channel,
which of the following would you choose?

And I will not sing the
Jeopardy song for you.

YVONNE NG: But you can
totally do it Cheryl. CHERYL SIEGEL: I wouldn't
torture you like that.
YVONNE NG: OK. I appreciate that.
And the results are here. Wow. Wow. LinkedIn.

And so Instagram
is the winner here. Does that surprise you?

Facebook I felt
like it is pretty--

yeah. I totally get that. But-- CHERYL SIEGEL: I'm
not that surprised

actually because I think others
are waning maybe in popularity. And Instagram is on the upswing.

And I think the
thing that surprises me is that nobody's on TikTok. I've been hearing
such good things.

But maybe it's just
our special group here that is not into it or--

so Instagram. I think that gives me
more fuel to the fire here to spend more time on it.

So I would have picked Instagram
too for what it's worth. Don't tell Mark Zuckerberg.
YVONNE NG: Or maybe we should.

No. I'm just kidding. OK. I think we're ready to open
up for some questions here.

Let's see. If you give us a second
to take a quick look.

So one of the questions
that had come up or suggestions that have come up
was just doing more advertising

campaigns. And I know that we've
kind of played around with that on
Facebook for a while

because in looking at our data,
which at MIT we love our data.

We found that so many people
come to OpenCourseWare

through that medium. Cheryl, are there some
advertising campaigns

that you could talk about? Perhaps-- CHERYL SIEGEL: Yeah. YVONNE NG: --some that
we ran in the past?

CHERYL SIEGEL: Yeah. Every February we
do a love campaign. And I have to say many of
these amazing ideas start

with Yvonne. She is often the
genius behind these.

So talking about February-- Valentine's Day-- and we
like to highlight stories

about how people love OCW
and how it's changed them but also how we
love our learners.

And so I look forward
to that one every year. Also, we do a back
to school campaign.

It's all wonky this year. But everybody is gearing
back up to go back to school.

And so we try to help by
providing intro courses, things students might interact
with on their freshman year

and need to get
caught up to speed. Also we did, thanks to
Yvonne, a whole campaign

about our scholar courses
that had little promos that had Jedi masters talking to
you about OCW scholar, which

is our sort of MOOCs
like experience. So I think another
challenge for me

thinking about this is we have
learners all over the world. And our two biggest
populations on social media

are people from the US
and people from India. And how do you make sure
your content is interesting

and engaging for all
kinds of communities.

And in terms of also timing. When do you post if
Mumbai is 12 hours ahead?

And what could be offensive
in another culture

that I don't realize
is happening. So I think those are
some big challenges. So any feedback from
anyone out there,

that would be super
helpful as well. High schools here have AP exams,
but that is limited to the US.

So that's not content
that's entirely relevant for everybody.

I also wanted to address the
question about certificates

that many, many people
ask us about certificates. And unfortunately, no.

OCW does not offer certificates. As you know, we don't
require any kind

of registration or sign in. We don't track where you are. So there's no way
for us to verify

that people have completed
any kind of coursework or mastered a subject.

So it's not something
that we offer. MOOCs can do that for you. But this is a vast
library of materials

that has been locked
behind gates for centuries. Right?

And we give it to you for free. And so that is
the situation now.

I know that a lot of
people would want that. But you can definitely
still put it on your resume

that you've learned
this material.

But we do get that
question always. YVONNE NG: Yeah. And I would add that
at Open Learning

there are quite a few
resources for people who are interested in
earning a certificate.

And so I would encourage you
to connect with our friends

at MITx, who run massive
open online courses. If you go to the MIT
Open Learning site

and on the home page
you can find MITx MOOCs. And those courses,
they're all free.
They are timed. There's great interaction.

You can get responses
to your questions. And if you choose to
get a certificate,

there's a nominal fee. There's a fee for that. But you could still access
all of those courses

and audit them for free. We had a question from
Van Vu, who wants to know,

does MIT guide people
to be teachers?

Or perhaps how does
MIT help educators?

Is that something you
could speak to Sarah? SARAH HANSEN: Sure. Well, I can talk about what
we're doing at OpenCourseWare.

Educators are really
important to us. They make up only about
10% of our usership.

But they're such
an important 10% because they are multipliers. They share our open resources
with many, many people.

So we really value them. And so in over
200 of our courses we have a special section
called instructor insights.

And that's where
I have personally interviewed the faculty member. And I've talked
to them about how

they taught on campus
with the course materials that they're sharing
on OpenCourseWare. So educators using them get
to find out how are they

used on the MIT campus? What do I want to
keep from that? What do I want to change? What do I want to build on?

It's a really neat way to pull
back the curtain on teaching. Usually teaching happens behind
closed doors at universities.

And MIT professors
are being radically open with their colleagues
around the world saying, hey,

take a peek in. Look at what's
going really well. Look at my challenges. Look at my iterations.

So I'd encourage anyone who's
working on their own teaching to take a look at
those insights.

We also have a special
educator portal where you can search
for courses that

use a particular pedagogical
strategy that you might be interested in, such
as active learning

or teaching with technology
or remote teaching now. We've just added that one.

So that's another
resource for educators. We also have a way to search
for our courses by particular--

like teaching materials. So you might want problem
sets with solutions or exams

with solutions in your
particular academic area. We make it possible to do that.

We're trying to make the
site as easy to use for you. But we have a long way to go.

And we're in the
process right now of refining those
pathways for educators

to make it even easier. So if any of you out
there have feedback about how OpenCourseWare
is working for you now

and changes that you
would like to see, please drop those in the
Q&A or in the spreadsheet.

And I will personally
take a look at those. YVONNE NG: That's great.

Marcel-- and sorry if I'm
mispronouncing your name, but Marcelo Aguayo from Paraguay
says he wants more video,

because it helps
improve his English. I wonder, Sharon, if you could
just talk about video with OCW

and how that works and how you
make those choices about which courses will have video
versus ones that don't.

SHARON LIN: So yes, I
definitely can speak about it from the role of being a
digital publication specialist.

So I think a lot of the
time, the deciding factor is actually from the faculty.

We usually provide content
as a snapshot about what is being taught at MIT.

And every year, every semester,
we have so many good courses. And we want to provide
an update on our website.

We understand our users have
always demand for more videos.

And we want to do more. But I think, especially during
the very challenging year

for the COVID pandemic, I feel
like we're very blessed that, even though we are
working remotely,

but we have a
fabulous video team who still went on campus to
work with the instructors

to capture a lot
of great videos. So it is our goal, is to provide
more videos, continue to do it.

We understand that
our users really love all the great videos. So that is definitely
what we're trying to do.

When we're standing at this
moment of our 20th anniversary, we look at what we have done.

And we know our users
love our videos. So we are hoping that,
in the next 20 years,

we can do more videos to
serve our learners, yeah. CHERYL SIEGEL: I'd actually
like to piggyback off that.

There are a couple of
questions about recruitment and how we choose which courses
to go on and updating courses.

So as I said, part of
my job, my main part, is working with the faculty
to get their materials up.

And it's a complicated
decision to get things up, because they are
pretty time consuming.

We only do about 60 a year. So it's what course
looks interesting that

fills a gap, what faculty
is willing to work with us. We may think that this
machine learning is fantastic.

But maybe the faculty
is wary of OCW. Or often, we get
a question about--

we'll get a response
that maybe next year. I'm not comfortable this year. So it's what's available,
who's teaching it.

Sometimes, if a course
is very hands-on, it doesn't translate
that well to OCW,
